header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.00 out of 64.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
  * recompile with fassociative-math (included in Ofast or ffast-math) to extend loop vectorization to FP reductions.
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:
C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<<image_row_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)

hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor and if some data references are common to consecutive iterations. This can be done manually. Or by recompiling with -funroll-loops and/or -floop-unroll-and-jam. Or with the unroll (resp. unroll_and_jam) directive on top of the inner (resp. surrounding) loop. You can enforce an unroll factor: #pragma GCC unroll N

expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 10.40 cycles. At this rate:
 - 5% of peak load performance is reached (6.92 out of 128.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 4% of peak store performance is reached (3.08 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 10.40 to 9.50 cycles (1.09x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
  * recompile with fassociative-math (included in Ofast or ffast-math) to extend loop vectorization to FP reductions.
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:
C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<<image_row_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
Only 11% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 10.40 to 0.83 cycles (12.55x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.

header:
The loop is defined in:
 - /usr/local/src/conda/python-3.9.19/Include/object.h:422,430
 - /usr/local/src/conda/python-3.9.19/Modules/itertoolsmodule.c:1947-1971

The related source loop is not unrolled or unrolled with no peel/tail loop.
This loop has 4 execution paths.
The presence of multiple execution paths is typically the main/first bottleneck.
Try to simplify control inside loop: ideally, try to remove all conditional expressions, for example by (if applicable):
 - hoisting them (moving them outside the loop)
 - turning them into conditional moves, MIN or MAX

Ex: if (x<0) x=0 => x = (x<0 ? 0 : x) (or MAX(0,x) after defining the corresponding macro)
